SourcedStatement: Before Sam Altman was ousted from OpenAI last week, he and the company’s board of directors had been bickering for more than a year.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: At one point, Mr. Altman, the chief executive, made a move to push out one of the board’s members because he thought a research paper she had co-written was critical of the company.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: Another member, Ilya Sutskever, thought Mr. Altman was not always being honest when talking with the board.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: And some board members worried that Mr. Altman was too focused on expansion while they wanted to balance that growth with A.I. safety.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The news that he was being pushed out came in a videoconference on Friday afternoon, when Mr. Sutskever, who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years, read him a statement.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The decision stunned OpenAI’s employees and exposed board members to tough questions about their qualifications to manage such a high-profile company.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The OpenAI debacle has illustrated how building A.I. systems is testing whether businesspeople who want to make money from artificial intelligence can work in sync with researchers who worry that what they are building could eventually eliminate jobs or become a threat if technologies like autonomous weapons grow out of control.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: OpenAI was started in 2015 with an ambitious plan to one day create a superintelligent automated system that can do everything a human brain can do.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: But friction plagued the company’s board, which hadn’t even been able to agree on replacements for members who had stepped down.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: Nearly all of OpenAI’s 800 employees had threatened to follow Mr. Altman to Microsoft, which asked him to lead an A.I. lab with Greg Brockman, who quit his roles as OpenAI’s president and board chairman in solidarity with Mr. Altman.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The board had told Mr. Brockman that he would no longer be OpenAI’s chairman but invited him to stay on at the company — though he was not invited to the meeting where the decision was made to push him off the board and Mr. Altman out of the company.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: In 2015, Mr. Altman teamed with Elon Musk and others, including Mr. Sutskever, to create a nonprofit to build A.I. that was safe and beneficial to humanity.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: They planned to raise money from private donors for their mission.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: But within a few years, they realized that their computing needs required much more funding than they could raise from individuals.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: After Mr. Musk left in 2018, they created a for-profit subsidiary that began raising billions of dollars from investors, including $1 billion from Microsoft.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: They said that the subsidiary would be controlled by the nonprofit board and that each director’s fiduciary duty would be to “humanity, not OpenAI investors,” the company said on its website.
Name: OpenAI
Title: null

SourcedStatement: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.
Name: email
Title: null
Justification: an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times

SourcedStatement: In the email, Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.
Name: email
Title: null
Justification: an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times

SourcedStatement: Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.
Name: Helen Toner
Title: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Justification: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

SourcedStatement: But Mr. Altman disagreed.
Name: Sam Altman
Title: chief executive of OpenAI

SourcedStatement: “I did not feel we’re on the same page on the damage of all this,” he wrote in the email. “Any amount of criticism from a board member carries a lot of weight.”
Name: Sam Altman
Title: chief executive of OpenAI

SourcedStatement: Senior OpenAI leaders, including Mr. Sutskever, who is deeply concerned that A.I. could one day destroy humanity, later discussed whether Ms. Toner should be removed
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: But shortly after those discussions, Mr. Sutskever did the unexpected: He sided with board members to oust Mr. Altman
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The statement he read to Mr. Altman said that Mr. Altman was being fired because he wasn’t “consistently candid in his communications with the board.”
Name: board members
Title: null

SourcedStatement: Mr. Sutskever’s frustration with Mr. Altman echoed what had happened in 2021 when another senior A.I. scientist left OpenAI to form Anthropic.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: That scientist and other researchers went to the board to try to push Mr. Altman out.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: After they failed, they gave up and departed
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: “After a series of reasonably amicable negotiations, the co-founders of Anthropic were able to negotiate their exit on mutually agreeable terms,”
Name: Sally Aldous
Title: an Anthropic spokeswoman

SourcedStatement: In a second statement, Anthropic added that there was “no attempt to ‘oust’ Sam Altman at the time the founders of Anthropic left OpenAI.”
Name: Anthropic
Title: null

SourcedStatement: After vetting four candidates for one position, the remaining directors couldn’t agree on who should fill it
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: The stalemate hardened the divide between Mr. Altman and Mr. Brockman and other board members.
Name: null
Title: null

SourcedStatement: During the call, Jason Kwon, OpenAI’s chief strategy officer, said the board was endangering the future of the company by pushing out Mr. Altman.
Name: Jason Kwon
Title: OpenAI’s chief strategy officer

SourcedStatement: This, he said, violated the members’ responsibilities.
Name: Jason Kwon
Title: OpenAI’s chief strategy officer

SourcedStatement: Ms. Toner disagreed.

Title: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Justification: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

SourcedStatement: The board’s mission was to ensure that the company creates artificial intelligence that “benefits all of humanity,” and if the company was destroyed, she said, that could be consistent with its mission.
Name: Helen Toner
Title: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Justification: an OpenAI board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

SourcedStatement: In the board’s view, OpenAI would be stronger without Mr. Altman.

Title: null

Title: null
